br.eti.rslemos.bitsmagic

Class Store

  • java.lang.Object
    • br.eti.rslemos.bitsmagic.Store

  • public class Store
extends Object
    This class consists exclusively of static methods that read or write bits over arrays of integral primitive type.

    The number of bits available per array element (element width) varies according to the storage class used:

    • byte: 8 bits (Byte.SIZE);
    • char: 16 bits (Character.SIZE);
    • short: 16 bits (Short.SIZE);
    • int: 32 bits (Integer.SIZE);
    • long: 64 bits (Long.SIZE).

    The total number of bits available (non-offlimits bits) is the product of arraysize by element width.

    For every method available in this class, the arguments that represent offsets should always be given in bits, and are 0-based. The bit mapping goes as follows (S is the element width in bits):

    • bits < 0: always offlimits;
    • bit 0: the least significant bit of first element;
    • bit 1: the second least significant bit of first element;
    • bit S-1: the most significant bit of first element (this happens to be the sign bit on signed types: short, int and long);
    • bit S: the least significant bit of second element;
    • bit S+1: the second least significant bit of second element;
    • bit 2S-1: the most significant bit of second element;
    • bits >= available bits (as previously defined): always offlimits.

    Offlimits bits are hardwired to 0: they always read as 0, and any value written to them is discarded. Except where otherwise noted, methods in this class should never throw ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.

    NullPointerException is thrown if the given array is null.

    All methods are inherently thread unsafe: in case of more than one thread acting upon the same storage the results are undefined. Also neither they acquire nor block on any monitor. Any necessary synchronization should be done externally.

    Since:
    1.0.0
    Author:
    Rodrigo Lemos

      • writeBit

                            int i,
                            boolean v)
        Writes the ith bit of the given storage.
        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        i - offset, in bits, 0-based.
        v - value whose contents will be written to data.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • fill

        public static void fill(byte[] data,
                        int from,
                        int to,
                        boolean v)
        Assigns the specified bit value to each bit of the specified range of the given storage. The range to be filled extends from offset from, inclusive, to offset to, exclusive. If to <= from this method does nothing.

        This method behaves as the following code: 

           for(int i = from; i < to; i++)
     Store.writeBit(data, i, v);

        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        from - offset, in bits, 0-based, of the first bit (inclusive) to be filled with the specified value.
        to - offset, in bits, 0-based, of the last bit (exclusive) to be filled with the specified value.
        v - value whose contents will be used to fill the specified region into data.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • readByte

        public static byte readByte(byte[] data,
                            int i)
        Reads as byte the 8 bits of the given storage starting from the ith bit. The range of bits read extends from i, inclusive, to offset i+8, exclusive.
        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        i - offset, in bits, 0-based.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • readBitString

        public static String readBitString(byte[] data)
        Returns a string representation of the contents of the given storage. The string representation consists of digits '0' and '1' for all non-offlimits bits. The first character of the returned string represents the 0th bit.
        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • readBitString

        public static String readBitString(byte[] data,
                                   int offset,
                                   int length)
        Returns a string representation of a range of the contents of the given storage. The string representation consists of digits '0' and '1' for bits ranging from offset, inclusive, to offset + length, exclusive. If any offlimits bit is touched, this method will throw ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        offset - start of range, in bits, 0-based, inclusive.
        length - number of digits returned.
        Throws:
        ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if offset is negative or if offset + length is greater than the number of bits available.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • writeBitString

        public static void writeBitString(byte[] data,
                                  String v)
        Stores a string representation into a range of the contents of the given storage. The string representation consists of digits '0' and '1'. The range of bits to be stored extends from 0, inclusive, to string's length, exclusive.
        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        v - string whose contents are stored into given storage.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • writeBitString

        public static void writeBitString(byte[] data,
                                  int offset,
                                  String v)
        Stores a string representation into a range of the contents of the given storage. The string representation consists of digits '0' and '1'. The range of bits to be stored extends from offset, inclusive, to offset + length, exclusive. If any offlimits bit is touched, this method will throw ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        offset - start of range, in bits, 0-based, inclusive.
        v - string whose contents are stored into given storage.
        Throws:
        ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if offset is negative or if offset + length is greater than the number of bits available.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • fill

        public static void fill(char[] data,
                        int from,
                        int to,
                        boolean v)
        Assigns the specified bit value to each bit of the specified range of the given storage. The range to be filled extends from offset from, inclusive, to offset to, exclusive. If to <= from this method does nothing.

        This method behaves as the following code: 

           for(int i = from; i < to; i++)
     Store.writeBit(data, i, v);
        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        from - offset, in bits, 0-based, of the first bit (inclusive) to be filled with the specified value.
        to - offset, in bits, 0-based, of the last bit (exclusive) to be filled with the specified value.
        v - value whose contents will be used to fill the specified region into data.
        Since:
        1.0.0

        public static void writeBitString(char[] data,
                                  String v)
        Stores a string representation into a range of the contents of the given storage. The string representation consists of digits '0' and '1'. The range of bits to be stored extends from 0, inclusive, to string's length, exclusive.
        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        v - string whose contents are stored into given storage.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • writeBitString

        public static void writeBitString(char[] data,
                                  int offset,
                                  String v)
        Stores a string representation into a range of the contents of the given storage. The string representation consists of digits '0' and '1'. The range of bits to be stored extends from offset, inclusive, to offset + length, exclusive. If any offlimits bit is touched, this method will throw ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        offset - start of range, in bits, 0-based, inclusive.
        v - string whose contents are stored into given storage.
        Throws:
        ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if offset is negative or if offset + length is greater than the number of bits available.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • readBit

        public static boolean readBit(short[] data,
                              int i)
        Reads the ith bit of the given storage.
        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        i - offset, in bits, 0-based.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • writeBit

        public static void writeBit(short[] data,
                            int i,
                            boolean v)
        Writes the ith bit of the given storage.
        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        i - offset, in bits, 0-based.
        v - value whose contents will be written to data.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • fill

        public static void fill(short[] data,
                        int from,
                        int to,
                        boolean v)
        Assigns the specified bit value to each bit of the specified range of the given storage. The range to be filled extends from offset from, inclusive, to offset to, exclusive. If to <= from this method does nothing.

        This method behaves as the following code: 

           for(int i = from; i < to; i++)
     Store.writeBit(data, i, v);
        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        from - offset, in bits, 0-based, of the first bit (inclusive) to be filled with the specified value.
        to - offset, in bits, 0-based, of the last bit (exclusive) to be filled with the specified value.
        v - value whose contents will be used to fill the specified region into data.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • readByte

        public static byte readByte(short[] data,
                            int i)

        i - offset, in bits, 0-based.

      • readBitString

        public static String readBitString(short[] data)
        Returns a string representation of the contents of the given storage. The string representation consists of digits '0' and '1' for all non-offlimits bits. The first character of the returned string represents the 0th bit.
        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • readBitString

        public static String readBitString(short[] data,
                                   int offset,
                                   int length)
        Returns a string representation of a range of the contents of the given storage. The string representation consists of digits '0' and '1' for bits ranging from offset, inclusive, to offset + length, exclusive. If any offlimits bit is touched, this method will throw ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException.
        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        offset - start of range, in bits, 0-based, inclusive.
        length - number of digits returned.
        Throws:
        ArrayIndexOutOfBoundsException - if offset is negative or if offset + length is greater than the number of bits available.
        Since:
        1.0.0

      • fill

        public static void fill(int[] data,
                        int from,
                        int to,
                        boolean v)
        Assigns the specified bit value to each bit of the specified range of the given storage. The range to be filled extends from offset from, inclusive, to offset to, exclusive. If to <= from this method does nothing.

        This method behaves as the following code: 

           for(int i = from; i < to; i++)
     Store.writeBit(data, i, v);
        Parameters:
        data - storage array.
        from - offset, in bits, 0-based, of the first bit (inclusive) to be filled with the specified value.
        to - offset, in bits, 0-based, of the last bit (exclusive) to be filled with the specified value.
        v - value whose contents will be used to fill the specified region into data.
        Since:
        1.0.0
